reviewText: Before this film no other film has even come close to scaring me. Those films mentioned above are like watching the Teletubbies in comparison to this film. I even consciously considered getting up and leaving the cinema through this film because I thought my mind just couldn't handle the tension any more. The action simply never stops once it starts. And, I won't spoil anything, but the first gory scene of the film: that kind of stuff shouldn't even be allowed! I never thought the line could be moved so far.

Just when you thought you had seen them all. Evil Dead, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Aliens, Halloween, Nightmare on Elm Street, Ring and now The Decent. Make no mistake about it... this horror is a bone-afide fully-fledged masterpiece that will have you on the edge of your seat well into the end credits. A group of six female buddies fronted by Juno (Natalie Mendoza) reunite to pit themselves against a forest cave only to stumble upon something exceptionally horrific, after they find themselves trapped following a rock fall. Deep underground their friendship worsens as they undergo a frantic struggle to survive. Part action, mostly horror, The Decent gets you right in there with the claustrophobia, crawling through tight spaces to suddenly unleash a bloodbath of absolute horror. When the screaming starts it does not stop and although there are many moments that I would love to review I would be doing you a great disservice to spoil any of it for you, including what is down in the caves. Take my word for it. When things get going this is the white knuckle ride you have been longing for. It is thoroughly violent and extremely upsetting for the sum of its fiendish parts. Just go watch it alone in the dark and then watch it again with your friends. You will be glad that you did. And calling this a Horror Cult Gem, means exactly what it says. This one is a keeper that can sit quite comfortably next to the best that are out there... and then some more. Don't even read past this review. Don't try and find any spoilers. Don't even bother with the trailer. Just BUY IT, watch it and give thanks to the director for reviving the horror genre with it.
This horror film was one of those gems that comes around too seldom. Kudos to the entire crew of this film and the female actors were explosive.

A group of women friends get together once a year for a sports adventure. They go to a cave in Appalachia and get trapped inside. While searching for an exit, they discover that they are not alone in the cave. There are humans living inside who have adapted over many generations to living in darkness, and they consider regular humans food.

Enjoyable movie, though the cave people are gross, and I don't like the ending.

Good movie, but unfortunately, this is the American cut. The original version ends ambiguously, but the American Cut removes the final scene, ending it on a cheap, non-sense jump scare. While that scene is also in the original, the scene that would follow afterward makes things a bit more clear (ironically, given that it gives us less answers), and at least keeps the scene in context with the rest of the film. Without the actual final scene, the ending to this movie is basically a genre-shift plot hole.

It's a better movie than it seems like it's going to be at the outset. There are things about the premise that are beyond absurd if you have some specialised knowledge of some certain things, but those are things that are probably fairly easy for an audience to suspend belief in. It's well shot and produced, and the acting certainly isn't terrible.

It's incredibly claustrophobic and very dark (in theme and lighting, heh) and would tie very well together from start to finish if this were not the American cut, which has altered the ending and made it make absolutely no sense and negates the pattern of events that lead up to it. It's an enormous mistake, and it would have actually been a much better movie if it had been left intact. 2.5 stars, as it stands.

This is one of those movies that chooses the type of movie it is with about twenty minutes to go.  Up to then it was a great survival thriller where a group of young women having been misled by one of them had to push deeper underground into the unknown, not knowing when they would run out of battery life for their helmets or if they would ever find a way back to the surface and get out.  I knew what was going to eventually appear in the movie, but the others watching this movie at the same time didn't.  Everyone had been enjoying the survival against the caving odds movie up to then, some like the new development, others not so much.

I found the first pre going down the hole year before part of the movie a bit unnecessary.  There is a cool scene involving some poles (oddly I didn't understand how blood suddenly started pooling from under the car though).  Really the movie could have just started with them driving to the caves and wouldn't have been any less understandable.

There's obviously way more light than there would be in real life.  Anyone who has been to tourist caves where the guide has everyone turn off their helmet lights knows just how dark it should have been.  But you could never have a caving movie with realistic lack of light as the viewer wouldn't be able to see anything.  But I did think the women should have been having a bit more difficulty seeing each other and other hazards then they do, especially in the last twenty minutes.  I also thought once the women learned they had been deceived, they should have been conserving battery life for their helmet and other lights a lot more.  Surely you'd just use the person at the front and maybe at the back's helmet lights, with the others keeping a hand on the person in front of them to ensure you have light when maybe need it.

From the start, the movie was kind of exciting and till the end, the movie seems ok to me. But comparing to the recent movies that I experienced such as <INSIDE><THE WOMAN> this movie was still a joke to me.

Anyway, the film started with a woman who's family had a car accident and all of her family instantly died from it.
After a year 6 of the girlfriends go on a extreme outdoor adventure which is I think is an annual thing.
They go to the deep inside a cave this time not knowing that there is strange beast like people who crawls ceiling, bites and eats human flesh.
All of them but just one who had her family all killed died at the end. The only woman survied by finding out the exit and survived.
The whole chase and hide thing was pretty intensive and blood shattering thing.
The shouting and barking of the beast like nature are pretty creepy. They look more like living dead.
First they were few, and then they were hundreds. And there were only 6 of the humans there who can fight.
Yes, the women were tough but they cannot fight enough to outpower hundreds of them. Besides, they are very powerful and brutal.
They use their teeth to bite and suck blood from human. They also can see in the dark I think.
It was pretty surprise knowing that is has a very good point at the imdb which was 7.2. As a horror film, More then 7 point means a great deal.
I think it has that high point because the movie knew how to make tension slowly and step by step way.
It was not all surprise thing with stupid sound effect.
This movie was not all original but knows how to make to audience feel the fear of narrow area, dark places and large number of unknown creature coming toward us.
It was a good movie to enjoy after all.

The Descent is an absolutely excellent horror movie- strong female protagonists with just the right amount of back story. Beautiful cinematography that heightens the fear. Brilliant "monsters", but so much of the horror element comes from the darkness and tight spaces. This cut uses the extended ending, which I actually think I like more than the original. I highly recommend to add to your horror movie collection.

I had high expectations for this movie; not unreasonably high, but I at least expected it to be entertaining.

The first 45 minutes was okay. The movie tricks you into thinking it's going to be adventurous, dark and scary. The characters are a mess; there are only two that really stand out - Juno the badass, and some other woman who lost her family in a car wreck and is extremely obnoxious, which is probably why her husband cheated on her (already forgot her name, that's how memorable the second most memorable character is). There is also some annoying girl who cussed a lot, and then a few other people who all look and sound the same.

When people start "dying" (slight spoiler, but I'm sure you expected deaths in this movie) you really have no idea what is going on. It's hard to tell who is being attacked or who is dying. It just looks like a mess of people all over the cave. The cinematography is a disaster.

Not scary, not exciting, overall pretty dull. 45 minutes of a bunch of girls talking, then another 45 minutes of some darkness and lights in a cave with people screaming and running everywhere.

Skip this one.

Let me just start of by saying, if you want to learn how not to act in a cave, than this is the movie to watch.. They do so many things that are terrible and sad to see happen to a place as beautiful and magnificent as a cave... even before things start getting dicey.

Six women meet in a remote part of the Appalachians to explore a cave hidden deep in the woods.  These women were quite realistic.  6 individual personalities.  Some were caring, some were hostile, one was deceptive and unbelievably arrogant.  Also they weren't the typically Holly Wood beauties.  These actresses looked like regular women.

They'd all suffered a tragedy a year before, one was still grieving.  Metaphorically each was facing her own monsters.  Once in the cave, they face monsters in a far more literal sense.  What they faced had pale skin.  Was completely blind, used radar to navigate - like a bat.  Climbed the cave walls and ceiling as easily as walking.  Had only sharp pointed teeth - completely carnivorous.

Throughout their time in the cave the women find ancient cave paintings.  The creatures ancestors had clearly been human.  How long they'd live in the cave is unclear, perhaps hundreds or even thousands of generations.  They'd been there long enough to evolve into a human subspecies, perfectly adapted for subterranean life.  To these Creatures of the Dark, regular humans were nothing but food.
Phenomenal movie, super scary, great story, nice to see empowered all-female cast.  The digital download was fine, no technical issues on that end.

i LOVE this movie.

it's nice to see a movie without men, and relatively free of discussion about them, and the cast of the descent really sells the flick. the women are all very believable as outdoor adventurers, and all of them are portrayed with profound competence. shauna macdonald as sarah is amazing, and she wears the tragedy of the film's opening behind her eyes in every scene. juno is pretty bada$$, and her raging chaotic neutrality makes her the catalyst of the film. natalie mendoza just just kills it. as an obvious homage and response to jc's deep freeze sausage fest, the thing, the descent shows us a wet, orifice-laden subterranean world in which women can be just as paranoid, impetuous, and untrusting as men (at least according to male filmmakers). but these women surely don't spend much of their time concerned with men, and it's a refreshing change of pace from, you know, every movie ever. the sequences that mimic the thing directly are accompanied by morricone-esque pulsations which brings a smile to face. it's liz phair's exile in guyville to the stones exile on main street.

much tension is created in the relationships between the characters--everyone has obvious friction with juno--and in the setting. we don't see any monsters till over half the movie has elapsed, but we see people crawling through impossibly tight underground spaces, repelling deep into the ground, and free-climbing long spans over bottomless darkness. the descent is utterly awesome, and the cool cave mutants are gravy.

gorgeously shot, ruthless, and generally smart, the descent really rocks (pun very intended). i'm a big fan of the tonally different second movie, and would love to see a third.

the blu ray is gorgeous, well-worth having in this format, as everything is crisp, clear, and visible, even in the dark.

This movie is an obvious prequel to the elder scrolls skyrim. It's about six women exploring a system of caves that have supposibly have never been discovered. After the tunnel to the surface collapses they are forced to to delve deeper that's when they encounter the falmer. Twisted pale blind carnivorous beings that have made their home underground. This is shortly after they have escaped the oppressive dwarves but before they have learned about tools or building homes. They are mercifully hunted in the tunnels and caverns while trying to escape. This movie is full of suspense and and jump out scenes that scare the s*** out of you. Just the scenery and the closed in feeling is unnerving. over all it's a pretty great movie and quite terrifying.

I usually don't write reviews, but I had to write one for this Film. Without a doubt, this has got to be one of the most annoying films that I have ever seen. I have never found myself rooting so much for the bad guys in a movie than this. The stupidity of the characters from start to finish made me want the creatures to literally tear their faces off slowly, from running around mindlessly in an unexplored cave to their constant arguing and bickering over absolutely nothing. One of the characters, Juno, was especially insufferable as a feckless wannabe whom I would have probably shot and killed myself, if I were ever in one of the other characters' positions. I would not recommend this movie if you have any trace of common sense. However, if you just want to watch six generally unattractive women get bitten by goblins then by all means go ahead. Otherwise not worth the money.

*Some spoilers*

I'm not a horror film junkie.  A lot of newer films look really lame but this one seems to be hyped a bit and I saw some comparisons made to Alien so I thought I'd give it a shot.

The first 20 minutes of this film are painfully dull.  We're supposed to develop some kind of bond with this group of women yet I could barely distinguish between them in the daylight, let alone once they got down into the cave.

So you endure the obligatory "lets get to know the victims first" and a few jump scares and then finally it gets rolling.  Girls get down into the cave and it's all giggles and oh isn't it so pretty down here until a crawl space collapses and they're trapped.  At which point we learn a couple of things

1)  The women who organized the expedition misled them about which cave they were going into and no one is coming to help them.
2) This cave is unexplored.  There might not even be a way out.

Ok so it's starting to seem a little scary as their survival looks unlikely, they are in a dark cold place with limited supplies and very limited light.  But wait, there is more.  There's also "them".  She sees something out in the dark.  She turns on the infrared on her consumer camera.  As she pans the floor we see piles and piles of animal bones. She scans slowly through the pitch black, building a huge moment tension and then suddenly it's right in front of her!  Pretty cool, but predictable.

As for the thing, it's basically a Gollum, only more human looking.  Men in soppy while suites.  When you see them in CGI they of course look fake,  but the times when they are not CGI they do look creepy.  Scary? Only because they use jump scare tactics, in fact they use them throughout the whole film, right till the very end.

So now it's a race, not only to find the way out of the cave, but to survive being hunted by these things.  So much running in the dark ensues, can't tell who is where, who is who, what is going on half the time, but I know that they are somehow progressing through the cave.

This goes on for ages and it's basically the movie.  Them running around, occasionally getting picked off by these things.  Some of them fight back and make these Gollums appear to be quite weak, even though they are physically larger than the women. So much gore ensues.  So much gore!  Then finally we sort of get to the end of the movie.  As in time has run out and the movie is almost over.  It's not really any further along in plot because there really isn't anything this movie is interested in doing anymore.  One the monsters hit the screen it's all about them.

So there are some things that are weird about this film.  I'm not sure if the people making it thought they were pulling it off, but they go through just about every cliche imaginable.  With elements that reminded me of Alien, Predator & Rambo (first blood).

The soundtrack is actually really good, I enjoyed it, but it felt totally disjointed from what your seeing on screen.  Sometimes it was actually funny.  Like they cut the soundtrack from another movie.  It just doesn't fit the style of this movie at all.  It would fit Alien or something older, more mature, indeed it would fit something that was actually scary quite well.

Anyway, there is just gore in this film, nothing is really scary at all and the characters are thoroughly boring for the most part.  Though I do at least appreciate that they aren't show in a sexy or erotic light.  The women are mostly normal, clever and knowledgable, though one does something really stupid and another other does something spiteful.

In the end it's like they planned the whole movie around reaching certain cliches.  Once one is reached it's swiftly to the next.  It's like watching your imagination if a teenager were describing this awesome film idea they have.  Nothing is earned here.  It's like the movie is not even aware you're watching it.
Really creepy. If you want nightmares, watch this!

One of the greatest psychological horror films to come out in recent decades. It plays with very primal human fears on such a great level. Fear of the dark, fear of being lost, fear of loss...they all come into play even before the Crawlers are introduced into the storyline. Sarah is still dealing with the aftermath of what happened to her husband and daughter, and is taking some pretty powerful medication that she knows could cause different psychological effects on her in the first place. This follows up with the scene of the soon-to-be physician, Sam, explaining to them the psychological dangers of caving in the first place, so you almost begin that part of the journey with a sense of dread, knowing that this very vulnerable woman is basically going to be your eyes and ears throughout the movie. And you wonder where Sarah is emotionally when she sees the first Crawler. Is it real? Is it the medication? Is it Sam's warnings? Then, the cave-in, Juno's revelation that they aren't where they're supposed to be, and everyone's sense of absolute betrayal, especially Beth not really believing that she was doing this as a sort of "gift" to Sarah, to get her back in the game. When the Crawlers make themselves known, the nightmare goes from bad to worse, knowing they are being stalked by something...the cracks in the group dynamic become even deeper. And the Crawlers are the icing on an already frightening cake. Being stuck in a system that has not been charted, with an injured team member, lights they know will go out and food and water they know will run out is bad enough, but adding in the threat of something that is clearly far more in control of the situation than the girls are is enough to put the fear of God into everyone. When the full depth of Juno's betrayal, and her almost obsessive attempts to make things right with Sarah become known, everyone pretty much assumes the same attitude as Hudson in Aliens...."Game over, man, GAME OVER!"

I also never found the gore factor to be over the top, I felt it was perfect for the Crawlers. They almost seemed to feed on the fear as much as they did on the bodies. "This is our territory, and we didn't invite you down here". The end of the film was also pitch-perfect. It brought the film full circle with its themes of primal fears mixed with everything Sarah had gone through. It was enough to leave me scratching my head, wondering just how much of what I had just seen was real. And I think it would have been an amazing ending to an amazing film. Shame they had to cash in on the money train and do that ridiculous sequel.

Overall, not a bad movie.

THE DESCENT is a movie I let sit in my video library for a while before actually watching it. Not because I was scared to, but mostly because I wasn't sure if it would be as good as I'd heard. Thankfully, my fears were assuaged when this turned out to be an effectively creepy and claustrophobic horror film. I'm not particularly scared of confined spaces but I can sympathize with those who are, and this film does a great job of creating an maintaining such an atmosphere for most of its running time. The basic plot is about these six women who go on a spelunking trip in the Appalachians. As a group, they've gone on similar adventures before, but nothing quite like this. As they get farther into the cave and deeper underground they are pushed to their limits and their sanity is tested, as well as their bond of friendship. They also discover that they may not be alone. Or are they?

 Generally speaking, the acting was sound and the characters were believable as a group of friends. There wasn't too much in the way of character development, but they were established well enough in the beginning that once things started to go south you cared about what happened to them. Of the six friends, only one is really given a back story, namely that her husband was killed in a freak accident after water rafting trip with a couple of her friends (who are in the main group). Her mental state is actually very important to the story, but in a way that I'll save for whoever wants to watch the film.

 Other aspects of the film that I thought very well-done were the cinematography, lighting and use of space. A lot of the film takes place in a cave underground, and it made good use of natural and artificial light to create a dark and mysterious atmosphere that kept you involved in what you were watching. You often get the sense that something could come out of the shadows at any moment and, in fact, there were a number of jump scares that utilized this very effectively. Although somewhat predictable in this regard, I didn't think they were overused and were germane to the story being told. Also, considering that this is a Neil Marshall film, the gore effects were well done and suitably gross.

 However, I do have a couple issues with the film as well. First, the score, while appropriate and engaging, was a little too insistent in parts. I don't really like when a film's music telegraphs how you're supposed to feel in a particular moment, and the music here gets used like that occasionally. With such a dark and claustrophobic film, I thought it would have been more effective to dial back the score a bit and let the scenes breathe a little on their own, creating a more natural sense of terror rather than inflating it with somewhat overblown instrumentation. I also thought that the story and character development could have been a bit more substantive. Instead of being rich and layered, it was minimal but effective.

 Overall, despite my misgivings about the score and thin plotting, I rather enjoyed this film. It's most effective at establishing an maintaining a tense mood and claustrophobic atmosphere that really works. At no point was I ever bored, although I would scratch my head at some of the stupid things that the main characters would do. But what horror film doesn't have characters who make ill-informed decisions at one point or another? What I got out of it what is a tense and thrilling survival horror with strong (but loosely defined) female characters and their descent into madness (the title works as a double-entendre). Highly recommended for genre fans.

A group of girlfriends get together and go on an extreme adventure once a year. One of the group, Sarah, had a horrible car accident on the last trip. She was okay but her husband and her daughter died. So she really isn't okay, she's having nightmares that sometimes seem like reality. She meets up with the girls again anyway and they explore a cave in Appalachia. The only problem is as they go along there's a cave-in and they are in a different cave than they originally planned on spelunking. They are lost in an unexplored cave with no hope of help coming to find them. If that wasn't bad enough, the cave is not uninhabited and soon they are fleeing from or fighting with some underground humanoids who are very hungry.

The movie has a lot of atmosphere once it gets into the caves. The story, with the claustrophobic climbing through rock tunnels barely big enough to fit them, is scary even before the monsters show up. Tensions among the group become very high and their friendship is tested and even broken some times. The monsters are horrifying to look at though they mostly appear in quick flashes, even during the fight scenes. The fights have a lot of editing, making them more tense to watch but not turning them incoherent.

If you want to see a really scary movie, this delivers the goods. Also, there's a lot of nice visual references to other films like The Shining, The Evil Dead, etc. Film buffs get a little reward too!

Parental Advisory: The gore level is pretty high. Plus there's some recreational alcohol and drug abuse along with the typical foul language in an R-rated film.

In an age where the vast majority of horror films are mindless trash with minimal scares, The Descent can be remembered as an effectively executed and genuinely tense outing. The basic set-up is this: a group of brazen women go spelunking in an uncharted cave. For the first 45 or so minutes, the film focuses on the growing tension between the women and the anxiety they feel as things start to go wrong. Right around the 50 minute mark, The Descent takes a complete left turn and goes from being a human vs nature survival film to a human vs bloodthirsty cave-dweller vs nature survival film. The situation was already scary enough without the monsters, but they were just the icing on the cake. Because the odds are so overwhelmingly against the girls, it is a total thrill to watch them try to survive and find their way back to the surface. Talk about gross-looking monsters! These 'crawlers' are thankfully not CGI and it allegedly took about three-and-a-half hours to apply the necessary makeup to the actors playing them. The choice of making the cast fully female is one that boosted the intensity in an interesting way. If it were mixed gender, there would probably be unnecessary sexual/relationship drama. If it were all-male, the film would lack heart and would become a bastardized version of Deliverance. With all women, it's just more fun to watch the transformation from sensitive young girls to savages. The contrast is stunning. The Descent was filmed in a very disorienting way which added much to the audiences terror. In many scenes where a girl is dangling on a rope over a bottomless pit, the camera will turn and maneuver in ways that cause the viewer to lose track of exactly what it is happening onscreen. And for a movie that takes place almost entirely in a cave, the minimal lighting is perfect for the atmosphere. The score is also terrifying, weaving through silent patches into loud, bombastic violins, horns, and drums. So far, the review has been nothing but the film's good qualities, which is not to say The Descent doesn't have its flaws. First off, its suffers from overly familiar horror territory, like characters making almost unbelievably dumb decisions. Like going into an uncharted cave for starters. The transition at the 50-minute mark isn't quite as smooth as it could have been. It happens rather abruptly when the movie is already suitably scary. Sarah's decision to stab Juno in the leg to avenge Beth's murder was dumb for multiple reasons. They could have helped each other escape and Beth should have mentioned to Sarah that Juno had only accidentally stabbed her in the throat. The little dream sequence at the end was also an unsatisfying cop-out to an otherwise above-average horror film. So The Descent had its ups and downs, but thankfully far more ups than downs.

We don't just sit there or run away from the monsters; we start swinging and slashing back! What would you do or turn into yourself inside in the same situation? The Descent is a descent into human survival instinct at it's fight or flight ,will to survive, animal ferocity finest! If you like the "Wolverine" attitude, THIS is a must have!

I love scary movies, but generally prefer less bloody ghost stories to horror. However, this one is a treat. The cast of adventurous female explorers is very engaging and believable, whether the characters they play are sympathetic or obnoxious. I enjoyed the groundwork of character development in the beginning, and the slow buildup to the truly terrifying 2nd half. One of the best things about this film is the fact that it didn't really need the antagonist creatures to be frightening. Just the story line of being lost in a dark and claustrophobic underground cave was scary enough for me. Although the eventual bloodbath was a bit over the top, this film was exactly what it set out to be. For that reason, I give it a 5-star rating.

The Decent is a movie which i've always heard about, i've heard countless people saying how terrifying this film is, I've even had a few people say "this is the scariest movie ever"
i never actually took interest in any of these statements considering i expected The Decent to be an average, run of the mill mainstream horror flick; but after a very long period of ignoring this film, and having viewed it; I can honestly say that i was wrong to assume such things. The Decent is a horror masterpiece.
The film has a very slow burn to it. Everything builds and builds, characters are given character, tension is piled on after each second passes; genuine suspense and atmosphere is key throughout this movie. A prime example would be the overwhelming feeling of claustrophobia. The entirety of the film takes place within tight, cramped underground tunnels which caused me to be on edge throughout the movie. The direction is tight and personal to each character, making you feel as if you're really trapped in these caverns with them; a majority of the shots are up close to the characters as they struggle through tight spaces and really adds to the confined, uneasiness that this film causes. Another point i'd like to touch on is the use of lighting as well as colors to evoke strong atmosphere. Many scenes take place in blood red lighting while others take place in green, blue, and orange lighting. I found this to be a rather enjoyable aspect of the film.

The Decent does however use quite a few jump scares... yet, i found myself caught off guard during them all. The film did a fantastic job of immersing me into this story. A few times I had completely forgotten I was watching a movie, and that's what makes the jump scares so effective. Until the climax you have no idea what to expect, but even then i found myself jumping and biting my nails from the suspense.
Another noteworthy addition is the soundtrack.
The soundtrack to this film is beautiful, and almost makes the first act of the movie feel like it's not a horror film  at all.
Bottom line, this movie is ridiculously well done, fantastic, amazing, beautiful to look at, and was really really satisfying.
I'll give it 4 stars just because it has strong female characters in it. That's kinda cool. Generally, I'm not a big horror movie aficionado.

The Descent is frequently found on lists of all-time best horror films, and the honor is well-deserved.  This tale of a group of young female spelunkers who become trapped underground with inhuman cave-dwellers is frequently terrifying.  I have seen both versions of the film - the original ending and the controversial "sanitized" ending.  Happily, this Blu-ray contains the original ending.

The story is gripping because of the great directing and interwoven relational conflicts; then we are shocked into a horror, thriller. It really is a likable flick.
they told a back story of a tragic woman trying to get out of her grieving for her loss of a child, then put her in a unexplainable situation that is a real life nightmare. It transitions so well because here we are witnessing a woman become something she never thought was possible, a killer and survivor. The film was shot superbly and the editing was top notch, (the cave scene intro was drawn out alittle too often) and it creates a susspensful effect. The Acting was amazing and each played the part well and was interesting. Special effects are top notch and I am a real stickler for that sort of thing. A great movie to buy, and recommend watching again in a few months or so.

The Descent,is deceptively simple on it's face & from the description,one might feel that it is just another run of the mill spook show. But somehow it manages to rise well above the usual fare.
This movie is truly frightening. From the disarming start,you are subjected to a jarring surprise,which makes it clear you can't trust it's predictability. The suspense builds from there. Once underground the sense of clausterphobia & being utterly trapped is unrelenting. And strategic startle events only intensify your general feeling of foreboding. And just when you think the Women in this  disturbing survival situation may be in a hopeless predicament,something truly horrifying makes itself known. There is a certain hero girl aspect to this movie. These are very capable women,& it is tempting to view them as feminist role models. But beware; it doesn't save them.
The video is quite excellent despite the largely darkened setting,& the audio presentation is top notch. The extras are very good. Of particular note is an actual helmet cam video of a spelunker in a real cave,worming his way through a horribly tight little tube without enough room to even turn around. If you have even a touch of fear of enclosed spaces,this will give you the Heebie-Jeebies!
All-in-all this is a mighty fine Horror Flick & I quite recommend it. Just don't watch it alone in the dark.

As a horror movie fanatic, every year I watch a few horror movies I haven't seen yet.  Most are simply ok, an occasional one is truly good, and most are crap.  This movie sadly falls into the latter camp.

Borrowing from HP Lovecraft's "The Beast in the Cave" et al, a bunch of pretty stupid women go into a cave and are annihilated by said stupidity.  That part is at least satisfying.  The ride there is veritable torture to the viewer however.  The following modern horror movie rules are strictly adhered to :

- Whatever rational normal people do in a given situation, these people do the exact opposite leading them headlong into the horrible situation they got themselves into

- All characters except one will be victims of their own insecurities such that their actions can only be kneejerk responses along a linear path inevitably killing them.  EG - the tough girl has to prove she's tough leading her to her eventual death

- The monsters will move silently right up to the person until the view shifts towards them, crook their head, then will shriek loudly, and kill the person in view.  They will also move inhumanly fast in ways that defy anything in nature, forgetting billions of years of evolution and the way predators in nature actually hunt

- All characters will die except the one that suffered some sort of trauma early into the movie which causes deep soul-searching and a more grounded approach to the situation they end up in

- That very same character will start out as a meek wallflower and will become the "true bada__" by the end of the film

- The plotline serves as a cautionary tale against stupid people doing things to prove how "bad" they are.  It's really a cautionary tale against stupidity in general

I give this film a single extra star for the following aspects : Decent acting, ok cinematography, good makeup work on the monsters.  Other than that?  Pass on this tripe. If you want a good monster movie of some undiscovered beast in a cave with a bit more initial plausibility, better acting, and less character stupidity I recommend "The Graveyard Shift" over this any day.
Very intense with pretty good acting. I saw this movie on cable and had to watch it again. I did not care for Descent 2 at all. Especially when compared to the first.

It's obviously difficult to make a genuinely scary movie!  There are so many out there that try but end up with a silly premise, poor cinematography, lame dialogue, bad acting, slow pacing, etc.  This movie has almost none of those problems.  And what could be scarier than  being in a cave?  YOu are at the mercy of battery powered flashlights and could fall off a precipice at any moment!  The characters are interesting and you connect with them they are so well-written.

SPOILER ALERT:  The creatures in that cave are pretty awesome...very scary.  Scary movies are completely ruined when the "monsters" look fake or completely cartoonish.  By the way, as most subterranean creatures do, these have lost the use of eyesight and depend on their hearing.  This makes for interesting situations.

I highly recommend this movie.
the Brits do a good job of making you believe this takes place in the States., plenty of scare, and blood.
I haven't watched it all the way through because it just seemed kinda dumb. maybe I will try again soon to see if I can get all the way through it.
I love this movie every time I watch it!  It's a very well done borrow movie.  I liked the second one as well, although it started differently than the first one ended.

The Descent is a film that is long overdue. This one is fantastic! It is about time for a movie about strong women kicking butt to protect theirs! This film starts out with a small group of girl friends loving the outdoors. Tragedy occurs and the group head to a National Forest (a fictional one) in the U.S to go caving. These women are strong and independent. When their lives are in danger, they do what they have to in order to survive.
Overall, this is a great film that both men and women will enjoy. I highly recommend this for a viewing at least once. It's a shame the sequel was a flop compared to this one.
Very much enjoyed this movie when it first came out. Had to own it, so thats what I did. Good acting also.
I really enjoyed it very much! A little to bloody for me, but had some what of a storyline! Had me sitting on edge of my seat!

Very mediocre.  Opening scene of movie is pointless and irrelevant to rest of movie.
The "creatures" they Fight are rip offs of lotr orcs.
2 stars because I like violence and blood, and the acting is actually pretty solid.. And the Asian girl is really hot.

I think movie took too much time building the climax, but I loved it anyway. I think it was boring in the beginning. But  after half time it progresses and entertainingly sets up the climax. Acting and direction was good.

There was much to commend the film until it got into the juicy parts which comprise the heart of the action. From then until the last few minutes, I could not keep track of Who Was Whom, what they were doing, to whom they were doing it,  what was being done to them, nor who ended how, and why them and not the others. I was able to overcome my aversion to caves, my aversion to a group going into unexplored caves with only one member knowing in advance that they would be going there, my aversion to people going into unknown caves without any notion of what they would find there nor how they would get out of the cave once they got in, and.............well, enough of that, I was getting along pretty well, thinking this was a much better movie than I thought it was going to be, then we plunged into darkness, in which we remained for most of the remainder of the movie. Now I admit there were flashes of light, occasional patches of certainty, but,  very artistically, in the key parts of the film, I could not make out to be sure what was going on (particularly as there was a lot of mud and guck on the characters to insure that you couldn't get a clear view.
From the reviews, you can assume that many were quite comfortable seeing all they wanted to see. They may have had better TV sets, better eyes or both. All I have sought to say was that, for me, it was a good female bonding movie which managed to irritate me once we reached the core of the film.

THE DESCENT is creepy, atmospheric, and keeps you riveted to the edge of your seat through it's living characters and the claustrophobic environment of an Appalachian cave. Once the subterranean monsters show up, however, it turns into the usual hide-from-the-monsters horror movie.

Normall I love monsters - I find them more interesting than the humans in 99% of horror movies. Well, this one was that rare 1% where I think the movie could have been better without the creatures. Well, except for a few scenes, but those were more a result of the character's REACTION to the monsters than the monsters themselves. Could have been caused by something else - maybe their growing apprehension and terror.

Overall, highly recommended for horror fans, especially those looking for a kickass horror heroine.

No romance with beautiful looking feminine characters having the capabilities and daring of supermen. I guess people really do believe in Buffy the Vampire Slayer. Nevertheless, the flick is a full course dinner of action.

A some what scary movie that I really enjoy. The concept that a group of women being trap made the movie interesting. And by some what scary it means that it is very hard for me to be scare in any horror movies
The movie was ok. It could have been much better. Far too much of screaming women for me. The effects were good.

I saw this movie in the theater and thought it was one of the most chilling films I have seen.  I picked up this
Blu-Ray to replace a DVD I have and have not watched it as yet but the reviews on line suggest the PQ is
top notch.
The movie was excellent. Great suspense built, great fear and ending! Really enjoyed it and would want to see it again

Clearly I am in the minority of viewers in ranking this on the lower end. There were certainly a number of environmental factors that may have played into my dissatisfaction; I may have liked it more on a big screen, and I saw it about eight years after it came out and am perhaps applying different standards. I also knew roughly what to expect from the plot going in.

On the positive side, there are the beginnings of character development and an initial story of loss. Of the six 'descendants', however, I only started feeling a connection to maybe two of them. I found it easy enough to predict which one would meet tragedy first; that I felt the need to guess was perhaps the first sign of boredom. I think character development is important, but more so as a means than an end. The end goal is that the audience cares about and connects with the characters. If that connection fails to take hold, then no amount of development will have been worth it and it might have been more worthwhile to save everyone the time.

I soon found myself killing time by deftly anticipating the need to lower the volume right before cheap, gotcha-type loud noises meant to make the audience jump. One could almost sense the ebb and flow of energy - and predict it. It's hard to respect using those gimmicks as crutches.

It was not until the final third of the film that it cut to the chase, and by then, I was lost. Even if I did not know what to expect like some of the other reviewers, I don't know how much I would have appreciated that the story essentially became a whole new movie rather than simply a matter of raised stakes. First it's about one thing, then it's about another.

The action scenes were dark and visually chaotic. Granted, this takes place in a cave. However, there's a right and a wrong way to do it. Swinging cameras around simply failed to give this viewer a good sense of who was where, when, and what was going on at any given moment. One might surmise that was point. Perhaps, but all things in moderation. It's one thing to have a sense of chaos; it's entirely another to have little sense of what's going on for what seem like minutes at a time.

There is the payoff of the macabre and, technical issues aside, some engaging action. It was just too little, too late in this reviewer's book.

Maybe it would have been an entirely difference on the big screen. However, in this day and age, good luck finding a showing.
Good BR release. No digital copy or extra features separate disc. Overall the transfer is good and this is a must for people who want to see the lowlight capabilities of your tv.

I was surprised at how much I liked this movie. I did expect the survival element to be present but the adding on the creeper twist (don't know if there's a name for these creatures, I streamed the movie) made the movie much deeper and more engaging for the viewer.

I really liked how these characters went through mini story arcs throught the film, dealing with trust, emotional recovery, clustrophobia, bringing out man's inner beast and relationships between characters. Also I liked how even when I knew one character and the viewer was about to get scared, no matter how many times I said "Scare in 2 seconds" I couldn't stop myself from shuddering violently.

Now there are three problems I have: one when the death scenes start it felt like characters were dying stupidly (later I found out that none of them died stupidly), 2nd the husbend at the beginning has an important role in the relationship between two of the females but it is extremely easy to miss. Hint he has a saying that comes up during the latter half of the movie. Finally while I don't mind the original ending for being different, I think the US version ended the film better, even though I usually complain yet expect those endings. The original ending felt a little unnatural dispite explaining the cake.

So if you've got a few bucks, prime or know a streaming site what are you waiting for?
The cave, the claustrophobia, the creatures, the gore, the story, the plot twists..  this film has it all.  A definite must own for horror fans.
You have got to have an open mind to like this movie. Heck I love the movie Prometheus although my friends think its weird.. only because they aren't nearly as intelligent as I am
Like a really good made for tv scary movie. Honestly impressed - and better than most horror films I've seen in the last few years
great suprises on many levels,the moviemakers could continue with more.wish I would seen it when it was first released.very original.
Had some pretty intense parts, and overall pretty good. If you're claustrophobic, there are a few parts that will give you anxiety.

I like horror with drama and mystery. Not blood and guts - just BOO!!! You'll get it with this creepy film. Great premise of friends who just want some action and fun for the weekend.  If nothing else it's a good popcorn film that will keep you interested till the end.

The fact this is a horror movie made as realistic as possible, is already a good sign. The monsters are very believable in their physical appearance and adaptability to their environment. The film has a good story line and the progression keeps the viewer interested. The suspense tricks, used in most
horror films is what makes them cheesy and hollow. This full doesn't do that.

As hard as it is to do these days, I watched this movie having not even seen a trailer or had the plot/key moments revealed through word of mouth. After watching the prerequisite introduction of the main character with a big black stain on her psyche from a personal trauma, I was ready for a ride through clich-land.  However, at almost every point where a clich starts coming into play, there is at least a slight twist to it that pleasantly surprises and further clinches ones interest.  The characters are well acted and obviously written with thoughtful attention.  Watching the main character's center shift as she is forced to confront her environmental situation along with her perceptions of those around her was enthralling.

  The first half of the movie was an exercise of psychological tension (assuming somewhere in you is the tiniest bit susceptible to claustrophobia) and really gives a sense of the women having the true bond of long-term friendship and love for each other.  By the halfway mark I was already going to be just fine with the rest of the movie being similar, but then a wonderfully eerie moment marks the beginning of a smooth transition to a much faster-paced, action-driven story.

  The second half retains the psyche-thumping moments of the first while radically changing the stakes of survival.  While the first half of the movie does inform you that this movie won't be bashful with displaying personal injury, the second half does not elect to throw gore-for-gore's sake moments at you, but instead deftly uses such events to cause 'Wham!-your tension meter just went up yet another notch, and yes, you did just clench whatever/whoever happens to be next to you' reactions.

  The final moments come in two flavors: Original UK and US.  I got to see the US ending, but afterwards read other reviews and learned of the UK ending.  Both are quite fitting, although I do wish I would have experienced the UK ending first, so if given a choice I would recommend going that route.

  The Descent is a truly excellent foray into the often-tread, seldom-inspired, cookie-cutter realm of horror movies.  It contains an excellent cast with well delivered dialogue, set into a well crafted world, presented with precise timing and excellent direction; a rare gem that shines brilliantly in a bloated, worn out genre.
A group of women unknowingly explore a falmer cave.  It turns out exactly how you think it would.  An interesting movie, quite dark and worth a watch if you enjoy the horror genre.

There are really two parts to the film. Part one: these women are battling themselves and nature. Pretty epic. Part two: Supernatural hell. Both parts are equally creepy and gory. I highly recommend it if you are a horror film fan.

Blu-ray transfer is excellent, both video and audio, as would be expected with a 2005 production.

The power of this film is how it works well on several levels using action, psychology, and the group dynamics of the six women as they attempt to survive and escape, not just one stressful, very physical and mental challenge, but a second very terrifying one simultaneously. Bottle this up in a claustrophobic environment inherently hostile to humans and that amplifies the level of terror.

The film is a UK production released in the UK a year before the US release with a different ending. This Blu-ray has the original UK ending (an unrated cut in US) and the modified ending with additional cuts released in the US as it received slightly higher ratings from US test audiences. Which cut to view appears as an option when selecting the main movie from the main menu. I prefer the original UK ending, but encourage viewing both and making one's own decision.
The story sounded great but it just wasn't done well. I did not a feel a connection to any of the characters....it could have been a good movie.

This movie was great, I didn't even notice that it had a limited budget until I read wikipedia.

I cant relate to this movie in real life but if I could, I would need ducktape for my ankles because it would have scared my socks off :)
This movie was predictable, had poor acting, and I actually hoped all of them would die in the end.  I gave this movie away after I bought it.

I enjoy this movie because it always seems to give me that creepy feeling.  No big star names but I do not believe any would have done the scenes that these women did.  How mentally tough are you?  I would like to think I could survive something like this but what makes it so creepy for me is that I am not sure.

This is such a badass movie especially on blu ray ! Great syory and the creatures are just awesome and is just a great job of how they did movie , overall its a great addition to any great horror movie collection on blu ray

It has a 5 simply because of how well it can capture and engage an audience. The Descent taps into our most common fears like heights, the dark, tight/narrow spaces, monsters, reality/unreality, and builds the suspense in a way that your eyes will bug out.
Honestly, halfway through the movie, I lost interest. Bottom line, this was a typical horror movie with very bad acting.
Fun and entertaining. good thought put into it. Scary, somewhat, mainly entertaining. Could not stop watching, ended good. I could live without watching it, but it passes time. Good for Prime.
i love caves and anything to do with caves,it is the cave monsters that turn me off,i am sure they can make a suspencefull and scary movie without the inevitable monster.
This is like watching 4 Sigourney Weavers at one time. Good horror flick. Simple concept with lots of scary surprises. I could watch again but next time with a big bag of popcorn.
The movie's plot is not all that great.  However, it does have its exciting moments for those looking for scares and a little bit of fighting action.

Where would I even begin? How about: the cast, writers and director - in 98 minutes - have provided more cliches than an 8th grader writing a term paper.  Stereotype, after stereotype.  Women's Liberation has been cast back twenty years, thanks to this movie.  I watched it - all the way through - hoping for more.  And I now sit, and wonder, how did we let women have the vote?

The Descent is easily one of the best horror movies to come out of the 00's, and also one of the finest of all time from the genre.  It blends an interesting synthesis that allows it to transcend the genre standards, while still fulfilling the basic desires of the horror fan.  The plot interweaves phobias, interpersonal struggles, and classic horror scares to allow us to be terrified psychologically, emotionally, and viscerally.  The characters are meaningful, and the actresses are excellent.  The director paces the movie well and sets up scenes flawlessly.  The score is beautiful and haunting, and the photography is both visually stunning and highly effective in creating a sense of terrifying claustrophobia.  The Blu-ray touts one of the finest pictures I've seen, and the audio track is rich and powerful.  Some nice special features also round out this excellent package.  This is hands-down a must own for horror fans.  You simply must not miss this superb movie.
We have an adventure club and make everyone watch this before we do any caving trips, it's a thriller that really puts you on the edge (especially right before going into a cave yourself!)
Loved it.  I found it to be thrilling and scary.  What more can I say?  I enjoyed this thriller movie.
This movie is very scary! It is also very very VERY gory. Good story line, not your average scary movie.

If you are into scary movies, this one is a must see.  The claustrophobic atmosphere this was shot in is enough to give anyone the chills.  Not to mention the things happening in this environment.  It starts with a bang and keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout.

I was surprised how good this movie was. I love a good horror movie and this certainly delivers. I was on the edge of my seat and had several good gasps. I've heard the sequel is good too...that's on my list.

One word sums up this movie; WOW! I thought it was going to be another boring movie but it turned into an awesome movie.

Sad about Juno. It's called survival. I think that Juno and the other survivor should have both walked out together at the end but hey what can you say?

Don't give up on this movie. It gets better and better including the end.

This movie was gripping and made me jump and gasp many, many times.  The Descent is better than most horror movies--for comparison, I watched all of the The Ring, The Thing, Ju-on, The Blair Witch Project and countless other horror movies with a resting heart rate and a bored expression the entire time (while in a dark house and alone, in hopes of getting scared).

You have to excuse the fact that the creatures down there are not very realistic and relish the fact that the main characters, six adult women friends, are strong and smart, mentally and physically, are wearing hiking boots and have proper equipment.  No one is wearing heels, no one is wearing a dress, no one has a crush on a guy, no one is frail, no one is stupid (with the one exception of the woman who lied about where they were); these things give the movie realistic characters that we can relate to and be scared when they are scared.

Toward the end, the fighting started going overboard and that one drastic choice one woman made at the end was disappointing, but the movie wraps up just fine in the end.  Overall, this was a solid horror movie.

Be sure to check out the original/intended ending on YouTube.
I watched this movie only because of the director, Neil Marshall. I really liked Dog Soldiers and enjoyed this movie as well.

The Descent is a great flick. I was lucky enough to catch it when it was on Amazon Prime for free. Lately it has been a few dollars to rent. I would still have paid to see it! I tend to like these kinds of movies however. Not those with gratuitous gore mind you - but rather creature feature flicks like we used to have back in the day. Highly recommended. (I might just buy this one to watch over again)

Pretty decent movie.  I thought the casting was great and it was nice to get an all-female cast in a rated R movie without nudity.  I won't give away the story, but I would watch this movie again.  I rarely jump during a movie and this one caused me to jump a few times.

These old-enough-to-know better girls in this movie should know: (1) Better than to take on a cave that no one has explored, (2) better than to let one of the main characters (whose running with one of her best friend's husband) lead the group, (3) better than making a plan to file with the park ranger that does not show the right cave, and (4) better for not thinking - period.  It does keep you on your knees crawling around into corners in order to stay alive or rack your brains trying to find a way out before the cave and its "dwellers" move in and take your backpack and a who lot more.  It's worth the rent.
Just good enough to be entertained for a while.  I don't really care too much for the unbelievable type movies, but did enjoy the scenes in the beautiful caves.
The ending in this one doesn't feel as complete as the original version. However, this movie is a great creepfest. Lots of scares and jumps. Very enjoyable.

I love this movie.

It's very entertaining and gory.  It satisfies the craving for suspense, gore, and mindless entertainment at the same time.
Genuinly creepy and disturbing. Good special effects make the a claustrophobics nightmare. The second one follows suit. Worth your time

Not bad! Worth the watch! The monsters or whatever were a little weird but oh well, still some scary stuff.

This movie never gets old. Hard to find horror movies like this that are unpredictable and well thought out (for what it's worth). It's really a sleepover favorite. Can't go wrong. Even the sequel is surprisingly decent. Awesome action parts. Nothing too "Oh come on!!!!" about it as far as tripping over nothing and walking into danger saying "hello, who's there" too much. Truly a classic to me. No other movie quite like it.
This is a good modern take on a wonderful H.P. Lovecraft story.  The claustrophobic element is great, the cinematography is good and the story keeps you entertained.

So many movies in this genre leave you wanting more. This movie was almost perfect. Believable acting, good story and a great flow that never leaves you bored. If you rewrite or possibly even omit the very last scene of the movie, it would be perfect. Like most horror movies they had to put that ignorant "twist"  or what ever you want to call it at the very end. It was just to good to need it and sadly it cheapens the experience. Overall, I highly recommend it and would say the last sequence is the only reason I gave it 4 and not 5 stars.

I made it through about an hour of this horrible picture, I kept hoping something would happen.  When a monster? finally appeared, it was like watching a silly kiddie horror film, after this I said I've had enough, everyone else watching it with me felt the same way.  This was the british version, uncut.

poor acting. somehow has rated 4/5 stars which means 4/5 people that rated it are idiots. has about 3 scary parts total. the acting is horrifying though. scariest part of the movie by a long shot was the acting.
